children.subject: Do you need to have a lot of linear algebra experience or is it enough to just know the concepts? I remember the concepts taught from math 54 and a little bit from data 100, but never did proof based questions like from math 110. If so, any recommendations to prepare for that until the semester begins?

You need either a lot of linear algebra experience or a lot of hard work if you want to do well in the class. It's not heavily proof based but I would say the best practice would be to review the linear algebra and SVD portions of 16B as that is the most similar.

Depends on how good you are at linear algebra. I am just OK, and for me personally, it was the hardest course I have taken. The homeworks were extremely long, and were due weekly. If you do not have a friend in the class, or time to go to office hours, I would not recommend it if you want a lighter schedule. It is not too hard to score decently in the class, however, provided that you finish all the assignments and put in the time you need to put in to this class. If you are great at linear algebra, it should be easier for you than it was for me.

history.content:
How is the course/workload for EECS 127? I'm confusion as to whether the class is difficult in terms of both workload and the prerequisites it requires because the Berkeley Time grade distribution seems a lot more generous than most upper div EECS classes.

If anyone has insight into how it compares with respect to classes such as CS 170, CS 61C, CS 188, CS 161, and other upper div CS classes, that would be really helpful. I am trying to take a relatively lighter course load in Spring 2020 and am looking to fill my schedule with 2 technicals (188 + something else). I have heard that CS 161 tends to be on the lighter workload side, but the grade distribution is worse than EECS 127, which I heard is tougher but apparently has a nicer distribution, so this contradiction doesn't quite make sense to me.
history.subject: EECS 127 Course Load + Grade Distribution
